newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Lee Kuan Yew warns against US-China clash on Asia.
newsitem.headline: Lee Kuan Yew warns against US-China clash on Asia.

text.p: Asia looks to a continuing United States presence in the region but this could change if America clashes with China over Hong Kong or Taiwan, Singapore Senior Minister Lee Kuan Yew said.
"A strong U.S. presence in the Asia-Pacific region has provided the basis for stability and growth of East Asia," Lee told industry leaders at a Pacific Rim Forum on Friday night.
"And this presence is more likely to endure if America and China do not clash over Hong Kong or Taiwan," he said.
He said that a "locking of horns" with China on an issue concerning China's relations with its own Chinese in Hong Kong or Taiwan was not tenable in the longer run.
It could shorten the much valued U.S. presence here, he said.
Hong Kong, a British colony for 150 years, will revert to Chinese rule on July 1.
Lee, predicting a change in the global order, said that in 20 years China could achieve the per capita gross domestic product of Taiwan or South Korea.
He added that if growth continues at present rates, China's gross national product could become the largest in the world.
"Such a massive change will be cause for discomfort to the existing world order as China will need some room at the top," Lee said.
He commented that while U.S. President Bill Clinton had decided to pursue a policy of deep engagement with China, it could be disrupted by domestic politics in the United States.
Lee said some groups wanted the United States to adopt a more confrontational policy for different reasons. Some wished to see China stumble before it becomes powerful.
"Was democracy and human rights in Hong Kong an issue before the collapse of the Soviet Union? I venture to suggest that if the Soviet Union still existed, the question would never have been raised."
